children.name: when you think sth may happen or may be true
maybe
children.definition: /perhapsA2 use this when you think that something may happen or may be true, but you are not sure. Perhaps is more formal than maybe.:
examples: có lẽ
▪ ‘Will you be there tomorrow?’ ‘I don’t know, maybe.’
▪ I wonder why she’s late - maybe she missed the train.
▪ The footprints belonged to a large cat, a tiger, perhaps.
▪ I’m not sure why I couldn’t sleep. Perhaps it was the coffee.
maybe not/perhaps not
có lẽ là không phải vậy
▪ ‘It’s not her fault that she can’t get a job.’ ‘Well, maybe not, but she should make a little more effort.’
▪ Housing prices will continue to rise, though perhaps not as much as was predicted last year.

children.name: may
children.definition: /might/could use this with other verbs, to show that something is possible, or likely, but you are not sure about it. May and might are more formal than could:
examples: có lẽ, có thể, có khả năg
▪ Take your umbrella -- it might rain.
▪ Hundreds of workers may lose their jobs if the strike continues.
▪ We could be home before midnight if the traffic isn’t too bad.
may/might/could have done something
có lẽ, có thể, có khả năg làm gì đó
▪ ‘Bruce isn’t here yet.’ ‘He may have decided not to come.’
▪ It’s a good thing we got her to the hospital right away -- the doctor said she could have died if we’d waited.

children.name: it is possible
children.definition: (that)/there’s a chance (that)/ɪt ɪz ˈpɒsbəl (ðət)ǁ-ˈpɑː-, ðeəʳz ə ˈtʃɑːns (ðət)ǁ-ˈtʃæns-/ use this when you think that something may happen or may be done, but that it is not very likely:
examples: có thể (có) / có một cơ hội (mà)
▪ I might have to work on Saturday, so it’s possible I won’t be able to come to your party.
▪ There’s a chance that I’ll be in California in October, so I might be able to visit you for a few days.
it is just possible (that)/there is just a chance (that)
nó chỉ là có thể (mà) / chỉ có một cơ hội (mà)
when something is possible, but very unlikely
▪ Tomorrow should be sunny but there’s just a chance of showers in the afternoon.
▪ It’s just possible we’ll finish the job by tonight, but it’ll probably be tomorrow.
outside chance/possibility
cơ hội/khả năng bên ngoài
▪ Martinez will need surgery, but there’s an outside chance he’ll be playing again before the end of the season.
slim chance/possibility
cơ hội/khả năng mong manh
▪ Sims has some numbness and weakness in her legs, and surgeons say there is a slim possibility of paralysis.

children.name: possibly
children.definition: /ˈpɒsɪbli, ˈpɒsəbliǁˈpɑː-/  use this when you think that something may be true, but you do not have enough information to be sure:
examples: có lẽ, có thể
▪ ‘Do you think she was murdered, inspector?’ ‘Possibly.’
▪ He’s playing in the US Open Golf Championships - possibly for the last time.
▪ Stone is possibly America’s finest film director.
▪ The cancer was possibly caused by exposure to asbestos.
▪ Trade between the two countries began in the 11th century, possibly even earlier.
▪ Many analysts believe interest rates will rise, possibly as early as next spring.
quite possiblyvery possibly
rất có thể
▪ The examination hall was vast, with at least 700 or 800 students and quite possibly as many as 1000.

children.name: conceivably
children.definition: /kənˈsiːvəbli/  if you think something may conceivably happen or be true, it seems unlikely but you can imagine that it is possible:

children.name: có thể tin được, có thể hình dung được
examples: ▪ Reservations are advised but you might conceivably find a hotel the day you arrive.
▪ It is still unlikely, but unemployment could conceivably begin to fall by the end of the year.

children.name: you never know
children.definition: /juː ˌnevəʳ ˈnəʊ/ spoken say this when you are not sure whether something will happen, because no one knows what will happen in the future:

children.name: bạn chẳng hiểu đâu
examples: ▪ I don’t think I’ll ever get married, but you never know.
▪ Why don’t you ask for a raise? You never know, they could say yes.

children.name: who knows? U
children.definition: who knows? spoken say this when you have no way of knowing whether something is true or not true: có trời mới biết

children.name: ‘Will you still be working here next year?’ ‘Who knows? Maybe I will, maybe I won’t.’
examples: Maybe he wasn’t telling the truth. Who knows?

children.name: possible
children.definition: if sth is possible, there is a chance that it may happen or it may be true:
examples: Heavy rain is possible later in the day.
possibly[adv] B2
He could possibly be released from prison within three years.

children.name: the possible effect on the health of local people
examples: There seem to be only twopossible explanations.

children.name: thepossible causesof a child’s learning difficulties
examples: You need to look at thepossible consequencesof your actions.
In Hollywood,anything is possible(= anything can happen, even though it may seem very unlikely ).

children.name: it is possible for sb to do sth
examples: It is possible for more than one person to win the competition.

children.name: it is possible (that)
examples: It’s possible that the letter got lost in the post.
It is possible that the children are still alive.

children.name: potential
children.definition: /pəˈtenʃəl/  a potentialproblem,advantage,effectetc is not a problem, advantage etc now, but it may become one in the future:
examples: tiềm năng, tiềm tàng
▪ For the first time she realized the potential danger of her situation.
Lần đầu cô ta nhận ra tình huống nguy hiểm tiềm ẩn
▪ It is important for manufacturers to identify potential problems at the design stage.
Điều quan trọng là các nhà sản xuất phải xác định được vấn đề tiềm ẩn ở khâu thiết kế
potential customer/buyer/student etcsomeone who may become a customer, buyer etc in the future
Khách hàng/người mua/học sinh tiềm năng
▪ a way of making the college more attractive to potential students
Cách làm cho trường đại học hấp dẫn hơn đối với sinh viên tiềm năng

children.name: there is a chance
children.definition: /possibility/ðeər ɪz ə ˈtʃɑːns, ˌpɒsˈbɪltiǁ-ˈtʃæns, ˌpɑː-/  use this to say that it is possible that something will happen: Có cơ hôi/khả năng
examples: there is a chance/possibility of: Cơ hội/khả năng của
▪ On the northern hills there is always the possibility of a snow shower, even in June.
Trên những ngọn đồi phía Bắc luôn có khả năng tuyết rơi, thậm chí là tháng 6
there is a chance/possibility that: Có cơ hôi/khả năng rằng
▪ Is there any chance that he will recover from his injury in time for the race?
Có khả năng nào để anh hồi phục chấn thương kịp lúc cho cuộc đua

children.name: can
children.definition: /kən, strong kæn/  if something can happen, it is possible for it to happen at some time: có thể
examples: ▪ Mistakes can occur, even in the most carefully controlled situations.

children.name: Sai lầm có thể xảy ra ngay cả khi trong những tình huống đã được kiểm soát kĩ lưỡng
examples: ▪ A lot can happen in two years.

children.name: Có thể xảy ra nhiều thứ trong 2 năm
examples: ▪ It can be warm in England, even in March.

children.name: Ở Anh có thể ấm áp, thậm chí là tháng 3
you never know
children.definition: /juː ˌnevəʳ ˈnəʊ/ say this to show that you think there is some possibility that something might happen, even though it seems unlikely: không thể liệu được
examples: ▪ I’d love to be a doctor, but I have to be very clever for that. Still, you never know.

children.name: Tôi thích trở thành bác sĩ, tuy nhiên tôi phải cần nhiều trí thông minh cho việc này, đến bây giờ vẫn không thể liệu được
make sth possible
children.definition: make something possible/ˌmeɪk something ˈpɒsbəlǁ-ˈpɑː-/
examples: làm cho trở thành hiện thực
▪ We are grateful to everyone who made this event possible.
Chúng tôi rất biết ơn mọi người đã tổ chức sự việc này trở thành hiện thực
make it possible for somebody to do something: làm cái gì đó trở thành hiện thực cho ai đó
▪ Satellite broadcasting made it possible for people all over the world to watch the 1960 Olympic Games.
Truyền hình vệ tinh giúp cho mọi người trên toàn thế giới có thể xem được Thế Vận Hội năm 1960

children.name: enable
children.definition: allow/ especially written to make it possible for sb to do sth that they want to do: giúp cho ai có thể ...

children.name: allow/enable somebody to do sth
examples: ▪ The Internet allows people to send messages all over the world.
▪ The sports school has enabled 10,000 youngsters to receive free tuition in a wide range of sports.

children.name: permit
children.definition: /pəʳˈmɪt/  formal to make it possible for something to happen or for someone to do something: cho phép
examples: ▪ I would like to go into this argument in some detail, but time does not permit it.
Tôi muốn đi vào chi tiết cuộc tranh luận này nhưng thời gian không cho phép
permit somebody to do something: cho phép ai làm gì
▪ Unit pricing is a system that permits the customer to compare the costs of products.
Đơn vị giá cả là hệ thống cho phép khách hàng so sành cách giá thành sản phẩm
weather/ time etc permittingif the weather, time etc makes it possible
nếu thời tiết/thời gian cho phép
▪ In summer, meals are eaten in the garden, weather permitting.
Vào mùa hè, người ta dùng bữa trong vườn do thời tiết cho phép
permitverb-tt- cho phép
[ I ]formalto make something possible
_The Chancellor is looking to lower interest rates, when economic conditions permit.
_We have arranged to play tennis on Saturday,weatherpermitting (= if the weather is good enough) .

children.name: pave the way
children.definition: for to make it possible for something to happen by producing the right conditions for it: tạo nền tảng
examples: ▪ Galileo’s achievements in physical science paved the way for Newton’s discoveries.
▪ In 1930's Germany, the depression helped Hitler rise to power, paving the way for the Second World War.

children.name: clear the way
children.definition: for to make it possible for something to happen by removing difficulties that existed before: mở đường cho
examples: ▪ The removal of trade restrictions cleared the way for a rapid development of East-West relations.

children.name: ▪ a vote that cleared the way for the ordination of women priests
possibility
children.definition: if there is a possibility that something is true or that something will happen, it might be true or it might happen :

children.name: a strong/good possibility
children.definition: something that is very likely
examples: There is a strong possibility that the drug causes similar damage in humans.

children.name: a real possibility
children.definition: something that is quite likely
examples: At this moment, a recession is a real possibility.

children.name: a distinct possibility
children.definition: something that is quite likely
examples: I knew there was a distinct possibility that I might fail my degree.

children.name: a remote/faint possibility
children.definition: something that is not very likely
examples: There's no point worrying about such a remote possibility.

children.name: a possibility exists
examples: The possibility exists that he misunderstood the data.

children.name: sth remains a possibility
examples: War remains a possibility.

children.name: consider a possibility
examples: Police In Glasgow are considering the possibility that the death may be drugs-related.

children.name: raise a possibility
children.definition: say or show that something may happen or may be true
examples: The government has raised the possibility of an early election next year.

children.name: rule out/exclude a possibility
children.definition: say that something will definitely not happen or is definitely not true
examples: We can't rule out the possibility that there will be more redundancies.

children.name: there is a possibility that
examples: There is a possibility that files could be lost if the system crashes.

children.name: possibility of
examples: We could not ignore the possibility of an enemy attack.

children.name: thepossibility ofan enemy attack
examples: There wasno possibility ofchanging the voting procedure.

children.name: there is a possibility that
examples: Unless there is some change in the economy, there is a possibility that the plant may close.
There’s alwaysa possibility thathe might go back to Seattle.

children.name: chance
children.definition: the possibility that something will happen, especially something you want :
examples: There’s always the chance that something will go wrong.

children.name: have/stand a chance
children.definition: of something
examples: (= it is possible you will do it )I think you have a good chance of getting the job.

children.name: give somebody a chance of doing something
children.definition: say how likely it is that they will do it
examples: He has been given a fifty-fifty chance of being fit for Sunday’s match.

children.name: increase the chance of something
examples: Certain foods increase the chance of heart disease.

children.name: improve the chance of something
examples: The book shows you how to improve your chance of success.

children.name: reduce/lessen the chance of something
examples: The talks were aimed at reducing the chance of war.

children.name: ruin any chance of something
children.definition: make it impossible for something to happen
examples: Drinking alcohol can ruin any chance of weight loss.

children.name: jeopardize any chance of something
children.definition: make something less likely to happen
examples: This could jeopardize any chance of a ceasefire.

children.name: a good chance
children.definition: when something is likely
examples: I think there is a good chance that he will say yes.

children.name: every chance
children.definition: a good chance
examples: There’s every chance that the baby will survive.

children.name: some chance
examples: There’s some chance of snow later this week.

children.name: a small/slight/slim chance
examples: He only has a very small chance of being elected.|There’s a slight chance of some sunshine in the west.

children.name: no/little/not much chance
examples: The prisoners knew there was little chance of escape.

children.name: a one in three/four/ten etc chance
children.definition: used to say how likely something is
examples: People in their 30s have a one in 3,000 chance of getting the disease.

children.name: a fair chance
children.definition: a fairly good chance
examples: If you work, you have a fair chance of passing the test.

children.name: a sporting chance
children.definition: a fairly good chance
examples: The proposals had at least a sporting chance of being accepted.

children.name: a fighting chance
children.definition: a small but real chance
examples: The Republican Party has a fighting chance at the next election.

children.name: a fifty-fifty chance
children.definition: an equal chance that something will or will not happen
examples: I’d say there is a 50–50 chance that the deal will go through.

children.name: an outside/a remote chance
children.definition: a very small chance
examples: He still has an outside chance of winning the championship.

children.name: a million-to-one chance/a one in a million chance
children.definition: when something is extremely unlikely
examples: It must have been a million-to-one chance that we’d meet.

children.name: chance of
examples: What are the team’s chances of success?
If we did move to London, I’dstand amuch betterchance(= have a much better chance )of getting a job.
There is little chance of her being found alive.
Chances are(= it is likely that )you’ll be fine.
